unnormalised: ## Feeling Stressed? There's an App for That, Yaar!
normalised: Feeling Stressed? There is an App for That, Yaar!

unnormalised: Hey everyone! In today’s crazy world, juggling work, family (hello, Auntie’s demands!), and just trying to *survive* feels like a full-time job in itself. It's no wonder mental health is taking a backseat. But what if I told you there’s a pocket-sized therapist available 24/7? I'm talking about mental health apps!
normalised: Hey everyone! In today’s crazy world, juggling work, family (hello, Auntie’s demands!), and just trying to survive feels like a full-time job in itself. It is no wonder mental health is taking a backseat. But what if I told you there is a pocket-sized therapist available twenty four seven? I am talking about mental health apps!

unnormalised: Now, I’m not saying ditch your Dr. Sharma and rely solely on your phone. But these apps can be a fantastic supplementary tool. Think of them as a mini wellness guru in your pocket, ready to offer guided meditations, mood tracking, and even cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) exercises.
normalised: Now, I am not saying ditch your Doctor Sharma and rely solely on your phone. But these apps can be a fantastic supplementary tool. Think of them as a mini wellness guru in your pocket, ready to offer guided meditations, mood tracking, and even cognitive behavioral therapy (C B T) exercises.

unnormalised: There are tons out there. Some focus on mindfulness, like Headspace or Calm, offering calming narrations that could make even rush hour traffic in Mumbai feel manageable. Others focus on tracking your moods, allowing you to identify triggers and patterns in your day. Imagine using one during Diwali week – you could actually track how the mithai impacts your mood (guilty pleasure, anyone?).

Others focus on tracking your moods, allowing you to identify triggers and patterns in your day. unnormalised: Plus, many of these apps offer communities where you can connect with others experiencing similar struggles. Sharing your journey, anonymously if you prefer, can be incredibly empowering.
normalised: Plus, many of these apps offer communities where you can connect with others experiencing similar struggles. Sharing your journey, anonymously if you prefer, can be incredibly empowering.

unnormalised: Now, do your research! Look for apps backed by credible research and developed by mental health professionals. Check the ratings and reviews, and see if it offers a free trial to see if it's right for you. The cost can vary, some offer basic free versions, while others have premium subscriptions costing Rs. 500- Rs. 2000 per month.

unnormalised: Remember, taking care of your mental health is just as important as hitting the gym or finding that perfect 1 BHK flat that's 600 sq ft in Bengaluru. So, download an app, take a deep breath, and remember, you’ve got this!
